Beside Mary, Joseph looks up to see a long procession coming, as the Three Wise Men draw near, with their retinue. | caption2 = <center>Ghirlandaio: ''The Sassetti Altarpiece''</center> }}
===Flemish influence=== From about 1450, with the arrival in Italy of the [[Early Netherlandish painting|Flemish painter]] [[Rogier van der Weyden]] and possibly earlier, artists were introduced to the medium of [[oil paint]]. Whereas both tempera and fresco lent themselves to the depiction of pattern, neither presented a successful way to represent natural textures realistically. The highly flexibly medium of oils, which could be made opaque or transparent, and allowed alteration and additions for days after it had been laid down, opened a new world of possibility to Italian artists.
In 1483 the huge altarpiece of ''[[Portinari Altarpiece|the Adoration of the Shepherds]]'' painted by [[Hugo van der Goes]] arrived in Florence. Painted as early as 1475 at the behest of the Portinari family, it was shipped out from Bruges and installed in the Chapel of Sant' Egidio at the hospital of Santa Maria Nuova. The altarpiece glows with intense reds and greens, contrasting with the glossy black velvet robes of the Portinari donors. In the foreground is a [[still life]] of flowers in contrasting containers, one of glazed pottery and the other of glass. The glass vase alone was enough to excite attention. But the most influential aspect of the triptych was the extremely natural and lifelike quality of the three shepherds with stubbly beards, workworn hands and expressions ranging from adoration to wonder to incomprehension. [[Domenico Ghirlandaio]] promptly painted his own version, with a beautiful Italian Madonna in place of the long-faced Flemish one, and himself, gesturing theatrically, as one of the shepherds.<ref name=W&M/>
===Papal commission=== [[File:Entrega de las llaves a San Pedro (Perugino).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.75|Perugino: ''[[Christ Giving the Keys to Peter (Sistine Chapel)|Christ Giving the Keys to Peter]]''|alt=Rectangular fresco. The scene is like Raphael's Marriage of the Virgin, above, which is based on it. There is a similar townscape and circular building in perspective, with an ancient Roman triumphal arch to either side. In the foreground, Jesus gives the keys of Heaven to St Peter, who is kneeling. To the right and left stand the other disciples and some onlookers, who are distinguished by Renaissance clothing. There are many more small figures in the square behind them.]]In 1477 [[Pope Sixtus IV]] replaced the derelict old chapel at the [[Apostolic Palace|Vatican]] in which many of the papal services were held. The interior of the new chapel, named the [[Sistine Chapel]] in his honour, appears to have been planned from the start to have a series of 16 large frescoes between its pilasters on the middle level, with a series of painted portraits of popes above them.
In 1480, a group of artists from Florence was commissioned with the work: Botticelli, [[Pietro Perugino]], [[Domenico Ghirlandaio]] and [[Cosimo Rosselli]]. This fresco cycle was to depict ''Stories of the Life of Moses'' on one side of the chapel, and ''Stories of the Life of Christ'' on the other with the frescoes complementing each other in theme. ''The Nativity of Jesus'' and the ''Finding of Moses'' were adjacent on the wall behind the altar, with an [[altarpiece]] of the ''Assumption of the Virgin'' between them. These paintings, all by Perugino, were later destroyed to paint Michelangelo's ''Last Judgement''.[[File:Ghirlandaio,_Domenico_-_Calling_of_the_Apostles_-_1481.jpg|thumb|380px|Domenico Ghirlandaio and workshop:''[[Vocation of the Apostles]]'', [[Sistine Chapel]]|alt=Rectangular fresco]] The remaining 12 pictures indicate the virtuosity that these artists had attained, and the obvious cooperation between individuals who normally employed very different styles and skills. The paintings gave full range to their capabilities as they included a great number of figures of men, women and children and characters ranging from guiding angels to enraged [[Pharaoh]]s and the devil himself. Each painting required a [[landscape]]. Because of the scale of the figures that the artists agreed upon, in each picture, the landscape and sky take up the whole upper half of the scene. Sometimes, as in [[Botticelli]]'s scene of ''The Purification of the Leper'', there are additional small narratives taking place in the landscape, in this case ''[[The Temptation of Christ (Sistine Chapel)|The Temptations of Christ]]''.
[[Perugino]]'s scene of ''[[Christ Giving the Keys to Peter (Perugino)|Christ Giving the Keys to St. Peter]]'' is remarkable for the clarity and simplicity of its composition, the beauty of the figurative painting, which includes a self-portrait among the onlookers, and especially the perspective cityscape which includes reference to Peter's ministry to Rome by the presence of two [[triumphal arch]]es, and centrally placed an octagonal building that might be a Christian [[baptistry]] or a Roman [[Mausoleum]].<ref name=Giaco>{{cite book|first=Massimo|last= Giacometti|title=The Sistine Chapel|year=1986}}</ref>
==High Renaissance painting==
The High Renaissance of painting was the culmination of the varied means of expression<ref>Manfred Wundrum "Early Renaissance" and "Renaissance and Mannerism" in ''Masterpieces of Western Art'', Tashen, 2007. Page 147</ref> and various advances in painting technique, such as linear perspective,<ref>Alexander Raunch "Painting of the High Renaissance and Mannerism in Rome and Central Italy" in ''The Italian Renaissance: Architecture, Sculpture, Painting, Drawing'', Konemann, Cologne, 1995. Pg. 308; Wundrum Pg. 147</ref> the realistic depiction of both physical<ref>Frederick Hartt and David G. Wilkins, ''History of Italian Art: Painting, Sculpture, Architecture'', 2003.</ref> and psychological features,<ref>Raunch pg. 309</ref> and the manipulation of light and darkness, including tone contrast, [[sfumato]] (softening the transition between colours) and [[chiaroscuro]] (contrast between light and dark),<ref>Wundrum pg. 148; Hartt and Wilkins</ref> in a single unifying style<ref>Wundrum pg. 147; Hartt and Wilkins</ref> which expressed total compositional order, balance and harmony.<ref>Frederick Hartt, ''A History of Art: Painting, Sculpture, Architecture''; Harry N. Abrams Incorporated, New York, 1985, pg. 601; Wundrum pg. 147; Marilyn Stokstad ''Art History'', Third Edition, Pearson Education Inc., New Jersey, 2008. pg 659</ref> In particular, the individual parts of the painting had a complex but balanced and well-knit relationship to a dynamic whole.<ref>Stokstad, pg. 659 and 662</ref> Painting of the High Renaissance is considered to be the absolute zenith of western painting<ref>Wundrum pg. 145 </ref> and achieved the balancing and reconciliation, in harmony, of contradictory and seemingly mutually exclusive artistic positions, such as real versus ideal, movement versus rest, freedom versus law, space versus plane, and line versus colour.<ref>Wundrum pg. 147</ref>
Most art historians state that the High Renaissance started around 1495 or 1500<ref>Stokstad pg. 662; Frommel pg.172; Hartt pg. 627; David Piper, ''The Illustrated History of Art'', Crescent Books, New York, 1991, pg. 129; Jacob Burchhardt, '' Cinerone'' 1841; Franz Kugler ''Handbook of Art History'' 1841.</ref> and ended in 1520 with the death of Raphael,<ref>Frommel pg.172; Hartt pg. 627; Piper pg. 129; Wurdram pg. 147; Johann Joachim Winklemann, ''Lives of Modern Painters, Sculptors and Architects'' 1672.</ref> although some say the High Renaissance ended about 1525<ref>Kugler; Honour and Flemming, pg. 466</ref> or in 1527 with the Sack of Rome by the army of [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]],<ref>Stokstad pg. 662; Lanzi.</ref> or about 1530.<ref>Raunch pg. 310</ref> Many cite Leonardo da Vinci's the [[Last Supper|''Last Supper'']], started in 1495 and completed in 1498, as being the first work of the High Renaissance.<ref>Stokstad pg. 662; Frommel pg.172; Hartt pg. 627; Piper pg. 129</ref> In his book, ''A History of Art: Painting, Sculpture and Architecture'', 1985, Frederick Hartt states that 1520 to 1530 was a transition period between the High Renaissance and Mannerism. The High Renaissance was dominated by three painters - Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo and Raphael; while Giovanni Bellini, Giorgione and Titian were the leaders of Venetian High Renaissance painting, with Correggio and Andrea de Sarto being other significant painters of the High Renaissance style.
===Leonardo da Vinci=== [[Leonardo da Vinci|Leonardo]] (1452-1519) spent his formative years training in the [[Florence]] workshop of [[Verrocchio]] before moving Milan where he worked from 1482-1499 before spending 1500-1506 back in Florence. Because of the scope of his interests and the extraordinary degree of talent that he demonstrated in so many diverse areas, he is regarded as the archetypal "[[Polymath|Renaissance man]]". But it was first and foremost as a painter that he was admired in his own time, and as a painter, he drew on the knowledge he gained from his other interests. [[File:Leonardo da Vinci 002.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.75|Leonardo da Vinci: ''[[The Last Supper (da Vinci)|The Last Supper]]''|alt= Rectangular fresco, in very damaged condition, of the Last Supper. The scene shows a table across a room which has three windows at the rear. At the centre, Jesus sits, stretching out his hands, the left palm up and the right down. Around the table, are the disciples, twelve men of different ages. They are all reacting in surprise or dismay at what Jesus has just said. The different emotional reactions and gestures are portrayed with great naturalism.]] Leonardo was a scientific observer. He learned by looking at things. He studied and drew the flowers of the fields, the eddies of the river, the form of the rocks and mountains, the way light reflected from foliage and sparkled in a jewel. In particular, he studied the human form, dissecting thirty or more unclaimed [[cadaver]]s from a hospital in order to understand muscles and sinews.
Leonardo achieved a degree of realism in the expression of human emotion, prefigured by Giotto but unknown since Masaccio's ''Adam and Eve''. Leonardo's ''Last Supper'', painted from 1495-1498 in the refectory of a monastery in Milan, became the benchmark for religious narrative painting for the next half millennium. Many other Renaissance artists painted versions of ''the Last Supper'', but only Leonardo's was destined to be reproduced countless times in wood, alabaster, plaster, lithograph, tapestry, crochet and table-carpets.
More than any other artist, he advanced the study and painting of "atmosphere". In his paintings such as the ''[[Mona Lisa]]'' (c.1503-1517) and ''[[Virgin of the Rocks]]'' (1483-1486) (the earliest complete work fully of his hand), he used light and shade with such subtlety that, for want of a better word, it became known as Leonardo's "sfumato" or "smoke". He exhibited a revolutionary use of colour by defining the transition between figures by colour modulation instead of by actual lines.<ref>Wundram pg. 148</ref> His work invited the viewer into a mysterious world of shifting shadows, chaotic mountains and whirling torrents. Another significant work of Leonardo's was ''[[The Virgin and Child with Saint Anne]]'' (c.1503-1519); the monumental three-dimensional quality of the group and the calculated effects of dynamism and tension in the composition made it a model that inspired Classicists and the Mannerists in equal measure.<ref>"Leonardo da Vinci" in ''Encyclopedia Britannica''.</ref> Apart from the direct impact of the works themselves, Leonardo's studies of light, anatomy, landscape, and human expression were disseminated in part through his generosity to a retinue of students.<ref> name=Vasari/</ref>
===Michelangelo=== [[File:Creación de Adám.jpg|thumb|upright=1.75|Michelangelo: ''[[The Creation of Adam]]''|alt= Rectangular fresco. God is in the act of creating the first man, who lies languidly on the ground, propped on one elbow, and reaching towards God. God, shown as a dynamic elderly man, is reaching his hand from Heaven to touch Adam and fill him with life.]] In 1508 [[Pope Julius II]] succeeded in getting the Florentine sculptor [[Michelangelo]] (1475-1564) to agree to continue the decorative scheme of the Sistine Chapel. The [[Sistine Chapel ceiling]] was constructed in such a way that there were twelve sloping pendentives supporting the vault that formed ideal surfaces on which to paint the [[Twelve Apostles]]. Michelangelo soon devised an entirely different scheme, far more complex both in design and in iconography. The scale of the work, which he executed single handed except for manual assistance, was titanic and took nearly five years to complete.
The Pope's plan for the Apostles would thematically have formed a pictorial link between the [[Old Testament]] and [[New Testament]] narratives on the walls, and the popes in the gallery of portraits.<ref name=Giaco/> It is the [[twelve apostles]], and their leader Peter as first Bishop of Rome, that make that bridge. But Michelangelo's scheme went the opposite direction. The theme of Michelangelo's ceiling is not God's grand plan for humanity's salvation. The theme is about humanity's disgrace. It is about why humanity and the faith needed Jesus.<ref name=TLT>T.L.Taylor, ''The Vision of Michelangelo'', Sydney University, (1982)</ref>
Superficially, the ceiling is a [[Humanism|Humanist]] construction. The figures are of superhuman dimension and, in the case of [[Adam and Eve|Adam]], of such beauty that according to the biographer [[Vasari]], it really looks as if God himself had designed the figure, rather than Michelangelo. But despite the beauty of the individual figures, Michelangelo has not glorified the human state, and he certainly has not presented the Humanist ideal of [[platonic love]]. In fact, the ancestors of Christ, which he painted around the upper section of the wall, demonstrate all the worst aspects of family relationships, displaying dysfunction in as many different forms as there are families.<ref name=TLT/>
Vasari praised Michelangelo's seemingly infinite powers of invention in creating postures for the figures. [[Raphael]], who was given a preview by [[Bramante]] after Michelangelo had downed his brush and stormed off to Bologna in a temper, painted at least two figures in imitation of Michelangelo's prophets, one at the church of Sant' Agostino and the other in the [[Apostolic Palace|Vatican]], his portrait of Michelangelo himself in ''[[The School of Athens]]''.<ref name=Giaco/><ref>Gabriel Bartz and Eberhard König, ''Michelangelo'', (1998)</ref><ref>Ludwig Goldschieder, ''Michelangelo'', (1962)</ref>
Michelangelo's later work, ''The Last Judgement'', painted on the altar wall of the Sistine Chapel between 1534 and 1541, shows a Mannerist style, with generally elongated bodies, which took over from the High Renaissance style between 1520 and 1530.
===Raphael=== With [[Leonardo da Vinci]] and [[Michelangelo]], [[Raphael]]'s (1483-1520) name is synonymous with the High Renaissance, although he was younger than Michelangelo by 18 years and Leonardo by almost 30 and died at the age of 37 just one year after Leonardo. It cannot be said that he greatly advanced the state of painting as his two famous contemporaries did. Rather, his work was the culmination of all the developments of the High Renaissance. [[File:Sanzio 01.jpg|thumb|left|upright=2.0|alt=Fresco of an arched space in which many people in classical costume are gathered in groups. The scene is dominated by two philosophers, one of whom, Plato, is elderly and has a long white beard. He points dramatically to the Heavens. A gloomy figure in the foreground sits leaning on a block of marble.|Raphael: ''The [[School of Athens]]'', commissioned by [[Pope Julius II]] to decorate a suite now known as the [[Raphael Rooms]] in the Vatican]] Raphael was born the son of a painter, so his career path, unlike that of Michelangelo who was the son of minor nobility, was decided without a quarrel. Some years after his father's death he worked in the [[Umbria]]n workshop of [[Perugino]], an excellent painter and a superb technician. His first signed and dated painting, executed at the age of 21, is the ''Betrothal of the Virgin'', which immediately reveals its origins in Perugino's ''Christ giving the Keys to Peter''.<ref name=DD/>
Raphael, who moved to Florence in 1504 and to Rome in 1508, unashamedly drew on the skills of the renowned painters whose lifespans encompassed his. In his works the individual qualities of numerous different painters are drawn together. The rounded forms and luminous colours of Perugino, the lifelike portraiture of Ghirlandaio, the realism and lighting of Leonardo, and the powerful draughtsmanship of Michelangelo became unified in the paintings of Raphael. In his short life he executed a number of large altarpieces, an impressive Classical fresco of the sea nymph, Galatea, outstanding portraits with two popes and a famous writer among them, and, while Michelangelo was painting the [[Sistine Chapel ceiling]], a series of wall frescoes in the Vatican chambers nearby, of which ''the [[School of Athens]]'' (1509-11) in the Stanza della Segnaturais is uniquely significant.
This fresco depicts a meeting of all the most learned ancient Athenians, gathered in a grand classical setting around the central figure of [[Plato]], whom Raphael has famously modelled upon [[Leonardo da Vinci]]. The brooding figure of [[Heraclitus]] who sits by a large block of stone, is a portrait of [[Michelangelo]], and is a reference to the latter's painting of the Prophet [[Jeremiah]] in the Sistine Chapel. His own portrait is to the right, beside his teacher, Perugino.<ref>Some sources identify this figure as [[Il Sodoma]], but it is an older, grey-haired man, while Sodoma was in his 30s. Moreover, it strongly resembles several self-portraits of Perugino, who would have been about 60 at the time.</ref>
But the main source of Raphael's popularity was not his major works, but his small Florentine pictures of the Madonna and Christ Child. Over and over he painted, in slightly different poses, a similar plump, calm-faced blonde woman and her chubby babies the most famous probably being ''La Belle Jardinière'' ("The Madonna of the Beautiful Garden"), now in the [[Louvre]]. His larger work, the ''[[Sistine Madonna]]'', used as a design for countless [[stained glass]] windows, has come, in the 21st century, to provide the iconic image of two small cherubs which has been reproduced on everything from paper table napkins to umbrellas.<ref>David Thompson, ''Raphael, the Life and Legacy'', (1983)</ref><ref>Jean-Pierre Cuzin, ''Raphael, his Life and Works'', (1985)</ref>
===Giovanni Bellini=== [[File:Giovanni bellini, madonna di brera, 1510, 01 adjusted.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Giovanni Bellini: ''[[Madonna and Child (Bellini, Milan, 1510)|The Brera Madonna]]'']] [[File:Pala di San Zaccaria (Venezia).jpg|thumb|upright=1.40|[[Giovanni Bellini]], ''The [[San Zaccaria Altarpiece]]''|alt= Oil painting. A large altarpiece in which the Madonna sits on a raised throne, with four saints and an angel as described in the article.]] A leader of the [[Venetian school (art)|Venetian School]] of painting, [[Giovanni Bellini]] (1430-1516) was born within a year of his brother [[Gentile Bellini|Gentile]], his brother-in-law [[Andrea Mantegna|Mantegna]] and [[Antonello da Messina]], but lived a decade longer than the first two and almost three decades longer than the latter. He was painting right up until his death and his works illustrate several influences. His early works show the influence of Mantegna with incisive lines and clearly delineated colours<ref>Wundram pg. 120; Ruanch pg. 366</ref> while after Messina's stay in Venice in 1475-1476 his works adopted a Flemish-like realism and luminous colours, which shows he was highly successful at adopting the techniques of oil painting brought by Messina.<ref>Stokstad pg. 655; Wundram pg. 120; Hartt pg. 563</ref> He was first the teacher of [[Giorgione]]<ref>Raunch pg. 388</ref> and [[Titian]]<ref>Raunch pg. 392</ref> but was later influenced by Giorgione, most notably in adopting tonalism wherein paint is applied in superimposed layers creating a soft diffused effect so figures and landscapes become more unified in atmosphere.<ref name="Mariolina">{{cite book|first=Mariolina |last=Olivari|chapter=Giovanni Bellini|title=Pittori del Rinascimento|publisher=Scala|location=Florence|year=2007|isbn=888117099X}}</ref><ref>Stefano Zuffi ''One Thousand Years of Painting'', Electa, Milan, 2001.</ref>
Bellini became the only great 15th-century painter to cross the threshold from the Early Renaissance to the High Renaissance style with works such as ''[[Portrait of Doge Leonardo Loredan]]'' (1501),<ref> Wundrum Pag. 147 and Pg.121; Hartt, Pg. 645</ref> wherein the Doge shows a calmness Bellini likely learned from Messina,<ref>Raunch pg. 361</ref> and ''[[Baptism of Christ (Bellini)|Baptism of Christ]]'' (1500–1502). Bellini, like [[Raphael]], also produced numerous small Madonnas in rich glowing colour, usually of more intense tonality than his Florentine counterpart.
Traditionally, in the painting of altarpieces of the ''Madonna and Child'', the enthroned figure of the Virgin is accompanied by saints, who stand in defined spaces, separated physically in the form of a polytych or defined by painted architectural boundaries. [[Piero della Francesca]] used the Classical niche as a setting for his enthroned Madonnas (with saints grouped around the throne), as [[Masaccio]] had used it as the setting for his ''[[Holy Trinity (Masaccio)|Holy Trinity]]'' at [[Santa Maria Novella]].
Bellini used this same form, known as ''Sacred Conversations'', in several of his later altarpieces [[San Zaccaria Altarpiece|such as that]] for the Venetian church of [[San Zaccaria]] (1505). It is a masterful composition which uses tonalism and extends the real architecture of the building into the illusionistic architecture of the painting, making the niche a sort of [[loggia]] opened up to the landscape and to daylight which streams across the figures of the Virgin and Child, the two female saints and the little angel who plays a [[viola]] making them brighter than [[Saint Peter|Saint Peter]] and [[Saint Jerome|Saint Jerome]] in the foreground.<ref>{{cite book|first=Mariolina |last=Olivari|title=Giovanni Bellini|year=1990}}</ref>
===Giorgione=== [[File:Giorgione tempest.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.4|Giorgione: [[The Tempest|''The Tempest'']]|alt= Oil painting. A mysterious landscape with Classical ruins. A man stands to the left, and to the right a nude woman feeds a baby]]
Despite the brevity of his career (he died in 1510 at about 35)<ref>Stokstad pg. 682; Hartt pg. 646</ref> and the low number of works universally agreed to be totally by his hand (as low as 4 or 5),<ref>Stokstad pg. 682</ref> Giorgione is often credited as being the founder of the Venetian High Renaissance style,<ref>Hartt pg. 645; Raunch pg. 388; Stokstad pg. 682</ref> although different scholars cite different reasons for asserting this.
One is his increasing use of gradations of colour and light (colour modulation), including sfumato, often achieved by tonalism,<ref name="Mariolina">{{cite book|first=Mariolina |last=Olivari|chapter=Giovanni Bellini|title=Pittori del Rinascimento|publisher=Scala|location=Florence|year=2007|isbn=888117099X}}</ref> to define the shapes of figures and landscapes and to create an atmosphere wherein all components of the painting are unified.<ref>Zuffi pg. 102; Wundram pg. 165; Raunch pg.646; Hartt pg. 646</ref> Some believe he may have been taught this by Leonardo da Vinci who is said to have visited Venice in 1501.<ref>Zuffi pg. 102; Wundram pg. 148</ref> In his ''[[Castelfranco Madonna]]'', 1505, the use of line and colour modulation are equally balanced but in ''[[The Tempest (Giorgione)|The Tempest]]'', c.1510, colour modulation almost entirely replaces line creating an artistic vision in which humankind and nature are combined.<ref>Wundram pg. 145 and pg. 165</ref> Some consider the ''Tempest'' one of the most important paintings produced in Italy as the components are held together by colour and there is a dreamy atmosphere of perfect harmony.<ref> Raunch pg. 392</ref> Giorgione was the first painter to assign a leading role to nature<ref>Zuffi pg. 103; Stokstad pg. 682; Raunch pg. 388)</ref> and whenever his paintings feature a landscape it becomes an integral part of the painting.<ref>Raunch pg. 388; Hartt pg. 647; Stokstad pg. 682</ref>
The ''[[Castelfranco Madonna]]'', when compared to Giovanni Bellini's similar The ''[[San Zaccaria Altarpiece]]'', illustrates another innovation of Giorgione - adjusting the directions and positions of the figures, such as the lance held by St. Liberale to the left and the folds in the Madonna's robe being placed in parallel, to more unify the subjects.<ref>Hartt pg. 648; Luffi pg. 103</ref> Lastly, Giorgione's paintings are always ambiguous in their meaning and open to different interpretations.<ref>Hartt pg. 647; Raunch pg. 388</ref> In ''[[The Tempest (Giorgione)|The Tempest]]'', the naked woman feeding a baby and the clothed man, and a flash of lightning, perhaps represents [[Adam and Eve]] in their post-Eden days, or perhaps it does not.<ref>Zuffi pg. 103</ref> Another painting attributed to him, ''[[The Three Philosophers]]'', may represent the [[Magi]] planning their journey in search of the infant Christ, or it may not.<ref>Zuffi pg. 102; Raunch pg. 388)</ref> None of Giorgione's paintings has ever had a certain interpretation.<ref>Raunch pg. 388</ref>
Until recent years, it had appeared certain that Giorgione painted the very first female nude that stands, or rather, lies, as a subject to be portrayed and admired for beauty alone with the ''[[Sleeping Venus (Giorgione)|Sleeping Venus]]'', 1510. While it had been long accepted that Titian finished the landscape of the painting after Giorgione's death, many art scholars are increasingly questioning if Giorgione painted the entire female body.<ref>Zuffi pg. 102</ref>
===Titian=== [[File:Tizian 041.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Titian: ''[[Assumption of the Virgin (Titian)|Assumption of the Virgin]]''|alt= whose dynamic three-tier composition and colour scheme established him as the preeminent painter north of Rome.]]
[[Titian]] (c. 1490-1576) trained in the workshop of Giovanni Bellini alongside Giorgione and then assisted Giorgione.<ref>Raunch pg. 392; Stokstad pg. 684; Hartt pg. 647; Zuffi pg.128</ref> Following Giorgione’s death, he was the monarch of the Venetian School for over 60 years.<ref>Hartt pg. 647; Zuffi pg. 128</ref> His early work shows strong influences of Bellini and Giorgione,<ref>Stokstad pg. 684; Raunch pg. 392</ref> but he soon he took the principles of form and colour announced by those two<ref>Hartt pg. 647</ref> and established colour, not line, as the major determinant in painting<ref>Hartt pg. 647; Wundram pg. 176</ref> thereby consummating the Venetian High Renaissance style.<ref>Raunch pg. 392</ref> He did this by applying colours of paint paste-like in patches alongside each other with loose and sweeping brush strokes.<ref>Raunch pg. 393; Zuffi pg. 128</ref> This brought out the light and colour in equal measure at the same time;<ref>Raunch pg. 396</ref> he was famous in his own day as the master of light and colour.<ref>Stokstad pg. 684</ref>
Another strength of Titian was the composition of his paintings.<ref>(Wundram pg. 176</ref> In the [[Pesaro Madonna]], 1519-1526, he moves the Madonna from the centre instead placing her at the upper vertex of a powerful diagonal line (as opposed to the usual vertical or horizontal) which still focuses the attention on the Madonna.<ref>Raunch pg. 393; Stokstad 684</ref> This was one of the first works to group figures in an circular, ascending structure.<ref>Wundram pg. 154</ref>
[[Assumption of the Virgin (Titian)|Assumption of the Virgin]], 1516-1518, also features diagonal lines (shaped by the cherubs located around the Virgin) which carries the triumphant message of the painting upward into the upper levels of the Church of Frari in Venice on whose altar it stands.<ref>Hartt pg.649</ref> This work was the first to have visual suggestion of movement;<ref>Wundram pg. 152</ref> all of Titian’s works have a new dynamism in the movements of people compared to the static elements of other High Renaissance painters.<ref>Wundram pg. 176; Raunch pg. 393</ref> The Assumption of the Virgin also features, like all of his paintings, glowing, deep, rich colours due to Titian’s applying layer after layer of paint, sometimes of different colours.<ref>Hartt pg. 649; Stokstad pg. 685</ref>
Titian was also the most sought after portraitist of his time and brought portraiture to the same level of esteem as narrative painting.<ref>Raunch pg. 400</ref> Highly notable are the ''[[Equestrian Portrait of Charles V]]'',1548, an equestrian picture in a symphony of purples, and the portrait of Doge [[Andrea Gritti]], ruler of Venice, perhaps Titian's most powerful portrait.
As Titian aged, he maintained a generally High Renaissance style until his last years, when figure was almost completed dissolved in the movement of colour,<ref>Hartt pg. 650</ref> so he became increasingly isolated from the mainstream of Italian painting which had moved almost completely towards Mannerism by 1530.<ref>Zuffi pg. 128</ref> In many ways, Titian can be considered the founder of modern painting.<ref>Zuffi pg. 128</ref>
===Correggio===
[[File:Cathedral (Parma) - Assumption by Correggio.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.35|Correggio: ''[[Assumption of the Virgin]]]]
[[Correggio]] (1489-1534), who never visited Rome, but must have seen the works of the Raphael, Michelangelo and Titian, worked in a personal High Renaissance style in Parma in Northern Italy.<ref>Hartt pg. 638; Raunch pg. 383</ref> He invented the open heaven filled with floating figures church dome which became a hallmark of the 17th Century Baroque period with his [[Vision of St. John on Patmos|''Vision of St. John the Evangelist'']], 1520-1524, in Parma’s San Giovanni Evangelista, and the [[Assumption of the Virgin (Correggio)|''Assumption of the Virgin'']], 1526-1530, in Parma Cathedral.<ref>Hartt pg. 639; Raunch pg. 383; Stokstad pg. 681</ref> One art scholar states that in the latter, Correggio creates a “dazzling illusion: the architecture of the dome seems to dissolve and the form seems to explode through the building drawing the viewer up into the swirling vortex of saints and angels who rush upwards to accompany the Virgin in to heaven.”<ref>Stokstad pg. 681</ref>
In those domes and other works, his bold use of perspective, usually by setting a dark colour against light colours to enhance the illusion of depth, is described as astonishing.<ref>Hartt pg. 638; Zuffi pg. 132; Raunch pg.383; Janson pg. 516</ref> His chief interest was painting light and he anticipates the effects to be achieved by Caravaggio at the start of the next century.<ref>Raunch pg. 383</ref> His mastery of foreshortening (causing objects to look shorter because they are angled to the viewer) to create perspective is described as perhaps the most skillful ever.<ref>Raunch pg. 383; Hartt pg. 638</ref>
In ''[[Jupiter and Io]]'', 1531-1532, Correggio painted a strong contrast between the luminous figure of Io and the soft but dark clouds filling the sky,<ref>Wundram pg. 174</ref> which seem to envelop Io’s gleaming body.<ref>Zuffi pg. 132</ref> Correggio was able to execute the diffuse effect of clouds, haze or mist perfectly<ref>Hartt pg. 383</ref> and together with colour modulation infuses his characters with a distinct sense of weightlessness.<ref>Wundram pg. 174; Janson pg. 516</ref> He painted flesh in a delicate, voluptuous manner that has never been surpassed<ref>Hartt pg. 639</ref> and presents a new concept of feminine beauty only rediscovered during the Rococo period.<ref>Raunch pg. 383; Zuffi pg. 133</ref> Correggio had many pupils but none carried on his style but he prefigured many components of Baroque painting.<ref>Raunch pg. 383; Janson pg. 518</ref>
===Other Significant High Renaissance Painters===
[[Andrea del Sarto]] (1486-1530), a Florentine, drew upon both Michelangelo and Raphael in his work, but went far beyond them in the portrayal of facial expressions and gestures, as evidenced in ''[[Madonna of the Harpies]]'',1517.<ref>Raunch pg. 341</ref> His figures show a greater individuality than earlier High Renaissance works while losing none of the nobility.<ref>Raunch pg. 341</ref> In the 1520s, he remained faithful to the ideals of the High Renaissance, such as in paintings’ compositions<ref>Wundram pg. 166</ref> and with the faces of his figures usually being calm and often beautiful, showing none of the torment of his Mannerist contemporaries,<ref>Hartt pg. 635</ref> some of whom were his pupils.<ref>Zuffi pg. 116</ref>
[[Lorenzo Lotto]] (1480-1556), one of the most important High Renaissance painters in Venice,<ref>Wundrum pg. 724</ref> also spent time in other areas of Northern Italy as, perhaps due to his greater focus on realist detail and on line than rather than colour compared to the Venetian school, he was not much appreciated in Venice.<ref>Zuffi pg. 126; Raunch 398</ref> While he painted a variety of subjects, he was an excellent portrait painter who had a superior ability to see into the soul of his subjects and to portray a depth of feeling in the painting.<ref>Raunch 398; Zuffi pg. 127</ref> He usually included other objects in the background or foreground of the portrait to portray the subject's character.<ref>Zuffi pg. 127; Raunch pg. 399</ref>
==Influence of Italian Renaissance painting== The lives of both [[Michelangelo]] and [[Titian]] extended well into the second half of the 16th century. Both saw their styles and those of [[Leonardo da Vinci|Leonardo]], [[Andrea Mantegna|Mantegna]], [[Giovanni Bellini]], [[Antonello da Messina]] and [[Raphael]] adapted by later painters to form a disparate style known as [[Mannerism]], and move steadily towards the great outpouring of imagination and painterly virtuosity of the [[Baroque painting|Baroque]] period.
The artists who most extended the trends in Titian's large figurative compositions were [[Tintoretto]] and [[Veronese]], although Tintoretto is considered by many to be a Mannerist. [[Rembrandt]]'s knowledge of the works of both Titian and Raphael is apparent in his portraits. The direct influences of Leonardo and Raphael upon their own pupils was to effect generations of artists including [[Poussin]] and schools of Classical painters of the 18th and 19th centuries. Antonello da Messina's work had a direct influence on [[Albrecht Dürer]] and [[Martin Schongauer]] and through the latter's engravings, countless artists including the German, Dutch and English schools of [[stained glass]] makers extending into the early 20th century.<ref name=DD/>
Michelangelo's [[Sistine Chapel ceiling]] and later ''[[The Last Judgment (Michelangelo)|The Last Judgment]]'' had direct influence on the figurative compositions firstly of Raphael and his pupils and then almost every subsequent 16th-century painter who looked for new and interesting ways to depict the human form. It is possible to trace his style of figurative composition through [[Andrea del Sarto]], [[Pontormo]], [[Bronzino]], [[Parmigianino]], [[Paolo Veronese|Veronese]], to [[el Greco]], [[Carracci family|Carracci]], [[Caravaggio]], [[Rubens]], [[Poussin]] and [[Giovanni Battista Tiepolo|Tiepolo]] to both the [[Classical Revival|Classical]] and the [[Romantic art|Romantic]] painters of the 19th century such as [[Jacques-Louis David]] and [[Eugène Delacroix|Delacroix]].
Under the influence of the Italian Renaissance painting, many modern academies of art, such as the [[Royal Academy]], were founded, and it was specifically to collect the works of the Italian Renaissance that some of the world's best known art collections, such as the [[National Gallery, London]], were formed.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} {{for|the village in Madhya Pradesh|Karanpura, Bhopal}} '''Karanpura''' is an archeological site near [[Bhadra, Rajasthan|Bhadra]] city of [[Hanumangarh district]] in [[Rajasthan]], [[India]]. It belongs with ancient [[Indus Valley Civilization]]. Harappan pottery has been found after excavation.
==Location== Karanpura is located on Nohar-Bhadra road near [[Bhadra, Rajasthan|Bhadra]] city of [[Hanumangarh district]] of [[Rajasthan]], [[India]].Administrationally Karanpura is in Bhadra tehsil of Hanumangarh district of Rajasthan. It is 8 km in the west from Bhadra and 125 km in the south-east from district headquarters Hanumangarh. Other famous Harappan site of this district [[Kalibangan]] is about 120 km in the west from Karanpura.
==Excavation== The excavation was done by a team under archeologist V N Prbhakar, archeological department of India, New Delhi.
The archeologists have found pottery and articles of Harappan period.<ref name="skeleton found in exacavation at Karanpura">{{cite news|title=A skeleton of a child found at Karanpura|work=Rajasthan patrika newspaper ,SHRI GANGANAGAR EDITION |date=9 Jan 2013 }}</ref> Excavations discovered many mud brick houses from early Harappan(3300-2600 BCE) to mature Harappan (2600-1900 BCE) periods.
Within the site, Harappan pottery, terracotta bangles, grinding stone fragments, beads of agate, and a terracotta figurine have been excavated.<ref>{{cite web|last1=ANS|title=A Slice of Harappa Found in North Rajasthan|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-in-school/a-slice-of-harappa-found-in-north-rajasthan/article5004547.ece|website=The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu}}</ref> Using the artifacts discovered at the site, trade routes have been linked that reach as far as Afghanistan during the Harappan civilization. Despite being small in size compared to other Harappan sites, the ancient city was a major long-distance trading hub.
Within the site, a rare discovery of 4 complete rhino bones was found, suggesting that the surrounding area was inhabitable with rhino.
A copper mirror was also found at the site, a rarity in Harappan culture, but more evidence of their extensive trading.
Pottery preceding Harappan culture has also been found within the site.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jaipur|title=Artifacts Link Karanpura with Harappan Civilization|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jaipur/Artefacts-link-Karanpura-with-Harappan-civilization/articleshow/21663829.cms|website=The Times of India|publisher=The Times of India}}</ref> Continuous findings within the site for up to 3 meters suggest a continuous occupation roughly since 2800 BCE.
Early Harappan findings of copper and lapis lazuli indicate long-standing acquisition and trade of raw materials up to the mature Harappan period. Steatite seals and an abundance of graffiti was also discovered within the mature Harappan portion of the site.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Prabhakar|first1=V. N.|last2=Jaseera|first2=C. Majid|title=Preliminary Results of Excavation at Karanpura, a Harappan Settlement in District Hanumangarh, Rajasthan|url=https://www.academia.edu/8797823/Preliminary_Results_of_Excavation_at_Karanpura_a_Harappan_Settlement_in_District_Hanumangarh_Rajasthan}}</ref>
Terracota like pottery and bangles which are similar with findings at other Harappan sites were found. On January 2013 a skeleton of child has been found. Seals similar to other Harppan sites also has been found in 2013-2014.<ref name="seals found at Karanpura">{{cite news|url=http://m.bhaskar.com/article/referer/521/t/240/MAT-RAJ-OTH-c-194-161415-NOR.html?1722|title=seals found at Karanpura|website=dainik bhaskar Hindi newspaper}}</ref>

[[New York University]] | occupation = [[Art historian]] | notable_works = | spouse = | children = }} '''Linda Nochlin''' (''née'' '''Weinberg'''; January 30, 1931 – October 29, 2017) was an [[United States|American]] [[art historian]], Lila Acheson Wallace Professor Emerita of Modern Art at [[New York University Institute of Fine Arts]],http://www.nyu.edu/gsas/dept/fineart/people/faculty/nochlin.htm and writer. A prominent feminist art historian, she became well known for her pioneering 1971 article "[[Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?]]".Nochlin, Linda. "Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?" ''ARTnews'' January 1971: 22-39, 67-71. ==Early life and education== Linda Natalie Weinberg was born the daughter of Jules Weinberg and Elka Heller (Weinberg) in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]Chinese University of Hong Kong, [http://ihome.cuhk.edu.hk/~b102437/congress/biodata.html#linda Linda Nochlin] and raised in the borough's [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]] neighborhood.Smith, Roberta. [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/01/obituaries/linda-nochlin-groundbreaking-feminist-art-historian-is-dead-at-86.html "Linda Nochlin, 86, Groundbreaking Feminist Art Historian, Is Dead"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 1, 2017. Accessed November 1, 2017. "She was born Linda Natalie Weinberg on Jan. 30, 1931, in Brooklyn and grew up in Crown Heights as a member of a wealthy extended family." She attended Brooklyn Ethical Cultural School, a progressive grammar school.{{cite web|url=http://arthistorians.info/nochlinl|title=Nochlin, Linda née Weinberg|last=|first=|date=|website=Dictionary of Art Historians|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=26 June 2015}} She received her [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[Philosophy]] from [[Vassar College]] in 1951, her [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in [[English studies|English]] from [[Columbia University]] in 1952, and her [[Ph.D]] in the [[history of art]] from the [[Institute of Fine Arts]] at [[New York University]] in 1963. ==Academic career== After working in the art history departments at [[Yale University]], the [[Graduate Center]] of the [[City University of New York]] (with [[Rosalind Krauss]]), and [[Vassar College]], Nochlin took a position at the [[Institute of Fine Arts]], where she taught until retiring in 2013.{{cite news | last = Pierce | first = Richard | title = CAA Names Linda Nochlin 2007 Distinguished Scholar | newspaper= NYU Today | date = 2007-01-29 | url = http://www.nyu.edu/nyutoday/archives/20/07/Stories/nochlin.html | accessdate = 2007-02-12 }} In 2000, ''Self and History: A Tribute to Linda Nochlin'' was published, an anthology of essays developing themes that Nochlin worked on throughout her career. Her critical attention was drawn to investigating the ways in which [[gender]] affects the creation and apprehension of art, as evidenced by her 1994 essay "Issues of Gender in Cassatt and Eakins".Nochlin, Linda. (1994). "Issues of Gender in Cassatt and Eakins" in ''Nineteenth Century Art: A Critical History,'' pp. 255-273. Besides feminist art history, she was best known for her work on [[Realism (visual arts)|Realism]], specifically on [[Gustave Courbet]]. Complementing her career as an academic, she served on the Art Advisory Council of the [[International Foundation for Art Research]].{{cite web|publisher=[[International Foundation for Art Research]]|url=http://www.ifar.org/about.php|title=About IFAR}} Nochlin was the co-[[curator]] of a number of landmark exhibitions exploring the history and achievements of female artists. * 2007 — "Global Feminisms" at the [[Brooklyn Museum of Art|Brooklyn Museum]]. * 1976 — "Women Artists: 1550-1950" (with Ann Sutherland Harris) at the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]]. ===Feminist art history=== In 1971, ''[[ArtNews]]'' published Nochlin's essay "[[Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?]]" in which she explored assumptions embedded in the title's question. She considered the very nature of art along with the reasons why the notion of artistic [[genius]] has been reserved for male geniuses such as [[Michelangelo]]. Nochlin argued that significant societal barriers have prevented women from pursuing art, including restrictions on educating women in art academies and "the entire romantic, elitist, individual-glorifying, and monograph-producing substructure upon which the profession of art history is based ". The thirty-year anniversary of Nochlin's ground-breaking inquiry informed a conference at [[Princeton University]] in 2001. The book associated with the conference, "Women artists at the Millennium", includes Nochlin's essay ""Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?" Thirty Years After". In the conference and in the book, art historians addressed the innovative work of such figures as [[Louise Bourgeois]], [[Eva Hesse]], [[Francesca Woodman]], [[Carrie Mae Weems]] and [[Mona Hatoum]] in the light of the legacies of thirty years of feminist art history. In her 1994 essay "Starting from Scratch: The Beginnings of Feminist Art History," Nochlin reflected on her awakening as a feminist and its impact on her scholarship and teaching: "In 1969, three major events occurred in my life: I had a baby, I became a feminist, and I organized the first class in Women and Art at Vassar College."{{cite book|last1=Broude|first1=edited by Norma|last2=al.]|first2=[[Mary D. Garrard]] ; contributors, Judith K. Brodsky ... [et|title=The power of feminist art : the American movement of the 1970s, history and impact|date=1996|publisher=H.N. Abrams|location=New York|isbn=0810926598|pages=130}} Nochlin deconstructed art history by identifying and questioning methodological presuppositions.Nochlin, Linda. (1999). "Memoirs of an Ad Hoc Art Historian" in ''Representing Women,'' pp. 6-33. She was an advocate for "art historians who investigate the work before their eyes while focusing on its subject matter, informed by a sensitivity to its feminist spirit."[https://books.google.com/books?id=OOnqAAAAMAAJ&dq=Representing+Women&cd=8 "Book Overview,"] ''Representing Women.'' ==== Orientalism ==== [[File:Jean-Léon Gérôme - Le charmeur de serpents.jpg|thumb|The Snake Charmer]]Following [[Edward Said]]'s influential 1978 book, ''[[Orientalism (book)|Orientalism]]'', Nochlin was one of the first art historians to apply theories of [[Orientalism]] to the study of art history, specifically in her 1983 paper, "The Imaginary Orient."{{Cite book|title=The Poetics and Politics of Place Ottoman Istanbul and British Orientalism.|last=Inankur,|first=Zeynep|publisher=Pera Museum Publications|year=2011|isbn=|location=Istanbul|pages=66|quote=|via=}}{{Cite book|title=Debating Orientalism|last=Elmarsafy|first=Ziad|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|year=2013|isbn=|location=UK|pages=184|quote=|via=}} Her key assertion was that Orientalism must be seen from the point-of-view of 'the particular power structure in which these works came into being,"{{Cite book|title=The Politics of Vision: Essays on Nineteenth-Century Art and Society|last=Nochlin|first=Linda|publisher=Harper & Row|year=1989|isbn=|location=|pages=34|quote=|via=}} in this case, 19th century French [[colonialism]]. Nochlin focused primarily on the 19th century French artists [[Jean-Léon Gérôme|Jean-Leon Gérôme]] and [[Eugène Delacroix]], who both depicted 'orientalist' themes in their work, including, respectively, [[The Snake Charmer]] and [[The Death of Sardanapalus]]. In Gérôme's "The Snake Charmer," from the late 1860s, Nochlin described how Gérôme created a sense of verisimilitude not only in his rendering of the scene with such realistic precision one almost forgets a painter painted it, but in capturing the most minute details, such as meticulously painted tiles.{{Cite book|title=The Politics of Vision: Essays on Nineteenth-Century Art and Society|last=Nochlin|first=Linda|publisher=Harper and Row|year=1989|isbn=|location=|pages=37–38|quote=|via=}} As a result, the painting appears to be documentary evidence of life in the Ottoman court while, according to Nochlin, it is in fact a Westerner's vision of a mysterious world. In Delacroix's "The Death of Sardanapalus" from 1827, Nochlin argued that the artist used Orientalism to explore overt erotic and violent themes that may not necessarily reflect France's cultural hegemony but rather the chauvinism and misogyny of early 19th century French society.{{Cite book|title=The Politics of Vision: Essays on Nineteenth-Century Art and Society|last=Nochlin|first=Linda|publisher=Harper and Row|year=1989|isbn=|location=New York City|pages=35–36|quote=|via=}} ==Personal life== Nochlin married twice. First, in 1953 she married Philip H. Nochlin, an assistant professor of Philosophy at Vassar, who died seven years later. She then married Richard Pommer, an architectural historian, in 1968. Nochlin had two daughters: Jessica, with Philip Nochlin,{{cite news|title=Miss Nochlin Plans Wedding in August|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/style/miss-nochlin-plans-wedding-in-august.html|accessdate=26 June 2015|publisher=The New York Times|date=April 19, 1981}} and Daisy, with Richard Pommer, who was depicted with Nochlin by the artist [[Alice Neel]] in 1973.{{cite web | url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/linda-nochlin-and-daisy-36578 | title=Linda Nochlin and Daisy {{!}} Museum of Fine Arts, Boston | publisher=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston | accessdate=26 June 2015 | website=Linda Nochlin and Daisy}} Linda Nochlin died at age 86 on October 29, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/10/29/linda-nochlin-trailblazing-feminist-art-historian-dies-at-86/|title=Linda Nochlin, Trailblazing Feminist Art Historian, Dies at 86|first=Andrew|last=Russeth|date=29 October 2017|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2017}} ==Awards== * 1967: Arthur Kingsley Porter Prize for the best article published in The [[Art Bulletin]] * 1978: Frank Jewett Mather Prize for Critical Writing, The College Art Association * 1977: Woman of the Year, ''Mademoiselle'' magazine * 1984-1985: Guggenheim Fellowship * 1985: Fellow, [[Institute for Advanced Study]] * 2003: Honorary Doctorate, [[Harvard University]] * 2006: Visionary Woman Award, [[Moore College of Art & Design]]{{cite web|url=http://www.moore.edu/support_moore/visionary_woman_awards |title=Moore College of Art & Design – Visionary Woman Awards Gala |publisher=Moore.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30}} * Fellow, [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] * Fellow, New York University's Institute for the Humanities * Fellow, American Philosophical Society ==Selected publications== Nochlin's published writings encompass 156 works in 280 publications in 12 languages and 20,393 library holdings.{{cite web|url=http://www.oclc.org/research/activities/identities/default.htm|title=WorldCat Identities|website=www.oclc.org|accessdate=30 October 2017}} * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|last2=Reilly|first2=Maura|title=Women Artists: The Linda Nochlin Reader|date=2015|publisher=Thames & Hudson|location=New York | ISBN=9780500239292}} * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|title=Courbet|date=2007|publisher=Thames & Hudson|location=New York, N.Y.|isbn=0500286760|edition=1. publ.}} * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|title=Bathers, bodies, beauty : the visceral eye|date=2006|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA.|isbn=0674021169}} * Nochlin, Linda. "'Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?' Thirty Years After." [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZxXrAAAAMAAJ&q=Women+Artists+at+the+Millennium&dq=Women+Artists+at+the+Millennium&cd=1 ''Women Artists at the Millennium,'']. Ed. Carol Armstrong and Catherine de Zegher. Cambridge, MA: [[MIT Press]], 2006. {{ISBN|978-0-262-01226-3}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/women-artists-at-the-millennium/oclc/223446291 OCLC 223446291] * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|title=The body in pieces: the fragment as a metaphor of modernity|date=2001|publisher=Thames & Hudson|location=London|isbn=0500283052}} * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|title=Representing women|date=1999|publisher=Thames & Hudson|location=London|isbn=0500280983}} * Nochlin, Linda. "Issues of Gender in [[Mary Cassatt|Cassatt]] and [[Thomas Eakins|Eakins]]." [https://books.google.com/books?id=sEP-GgAACAAJ&dq=Nineteenth+Century+Art:+A+Critical+History&cd=1 ''Nineteenth Century Art: A Critical History,'']. Ed. Thomas Crow, [[Brian Lukacher]], Linda Nochlin and Frances K. Pohl. London: Thames & Hudson, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-500-28683-8}}; {{ISBN|0-500-28683-3}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/nineteenth-century-art-a-critical-history/oclc/137221626 OCLC 137221626] * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|title=The politics of vision: essays on nineteenth-century art and society|date=1991|publisher=Harper & Row|location=New York|isbn=0064301877|edition=2. [print.].}} * {{cite book|last1=Nochlin|first1=Linda|title=Women, art, and power, and other essays.|date=1988|publisher=HarperCollins|location=New York|isbn=0064301834}} * Nochlin, Linda. "Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?" ''[[ARTnews]]'' January 1971: 22-39, 67-71. * Nochlin, Linda. [https://books.google.com/books?id=6woePwAACAAJ&dq=realism+linda+nochlin&hl=en&ei=kibTTZmZCcrB0AHvvuXQCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ "Realism."] New York: [[Penguin Books]], 1971. "Memoirs of an Ad Hoc Art Historian" in [https://books.google.com/books?id=OOnqAAAAMAAJ&dq=Representing+Women&cd=8 ''Representing Women.''] London: Thames & Hudson. {{ISBN|978-0-500-28098-0}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/representing-women/oclc/185808272 OCLC 185808272]. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100618033320/http://nyih.as.nyu.edu/object/LindaNochlin.html NYU: Linda Nochlin] *[http://ihome.cuhk.edu.hk/~b102437/congress/biodata.html#linda Linda Nochlin biography and c. v.] provided by the [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]] in conjunction with the International Congress on Culture and Humanity in the New Millennium: "The Future of Human Values", 8–10 January 2000, Hong Kong {{Feminist art movement in the United States}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nochlin, Linda}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:American art historians]] [[Category:Feminist historians]] [[Category:Vassar College alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Women's history]] [[Category:New York University Institute of Fine Arts alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University people]] [[Category:Yale University faculty]] [[Category:City University of New York faculty]] [[Category:New York University Institute of Fine Arts faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:American women historians]] [[Category:Women art historians]] [[Category:Vassar College faculty]] [[Category:People from Crown Heights, Brooklyn]] [[Category:Historians from New York (state)]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} [[File:Professor Norman Gash.JPG|thumb|right|140px|Norman Gash]]'''Norman Gash''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|FBA|FRSE|FRHistS|FRSL}} (16 January 1912 in [[Meerut]], [[British Raj]] – 1 May 2009 in [[Somerset]]) was a British historian, notable for a two-volume biography of British prime minister [[Robert Peel|Sir Robert Peel]]. He was professor of modern history at the [[University of St Andrews]] from 1955–80 and specialised in the 19th century.
== Early life == Gash was born in [[Meerut]], [[United Provinces of Agra and Oudh|United Provinces]] (now [[Uttar Pradesh]]) in 1912, the son of Frederick Gash, a soldier in the [[Royal Berkshire Regiment]], and of Kate Gash, ''née'' Hunt. He attended Wilson Road School and Palmer School in Reading, before gaining a scholarship to [[Reading School]]. He then attended [[St John's College, Oxford|St John's College, Oxford]] as a scholar, where he took a First in History in 1933. He subsequently completed a [[Bachelor of Letters|B.Litt.]] thesis on '‘The rural unrest in England in 1830 with special reference to Berkshire'.
==Biography of Sir Robert Peel== The first volume of Gash's biography of Sir Robert Peel ''Mr Secretary Peel'' (1961) followed his life up until 1830, including his successful period at the Home Office in the 1820s and as far as [[Catholic Emancipation]]. The second volume ''Sir Robert Peel'' (1972) covered his opposition to the [[Reform Act 1832|Great Reform Act]] and his tenures as Prime Minister from 1834-5 and 1841-6. Gash argued that Peel's reforms were paramount in ending the "hungry forties" and bringing about Victorian prosperity. Though Gash's interpretations of Peel have been challenged in recent decades, by historians including [[Boyd Hilton]], this work remains the definitive Peel biography.
==Works== * ''Mr Secretary Peel'' (1961) * ''Reaction and Reconstruction in English Politics 1832-52'' (1965) * ''Age of Peel'' (1968) * ''Politics in the Age of Peel'' (1971) * ''Sir Robert Peel'' (1972) * ''Gash: Aristocracy People: Britain 1815-65'' (1980) * ''Lord Liverpool - the Life and Political Career of [[Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool|Robert Banks Jenkinson]], 2nd Earl Liverpool'' (1985) * ''Pillars of Government and Other Essays on State and Society, 1770-1880'' (1986) * ''Wellington: Studies in the Political and Military Career of the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|First Duke of Wellington]]'' (1990) * ''Wellington Anecdotes'' (1992) * ''[[Robert Smith Surtees|Robert Surtees]] and Early Victorian Society'' (1993)
==External links== * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/books-obituaries/5339626/Professor-Norman-Gash.html Obituary: Norman Gash,] ''Daily Telegraph'', 17 May 2009 * Links to biographical memoirs of fellows of the British Academy, including Norman Gash [https://web.archive.org/web/20140327234312/http://www.britac.ac.uk/memoirs/11.cfm]
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Party Foundation Day |type = national |image = Dprk pyongyang tpk monument 05.jpg |imagesize = |caption =[[Monument to Party Founding]] in Pyongyang |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = {{flag|North Korea}} |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = Founding of the [[North Korea Bureau of the Communist Party of Korea|North Korea Bureau]] of the [[Communist Party of Korea]] (1945), a predecessor to the [[Workers' Party of Korea]] |begins = |ends = |date = 10 October |scheduling = same day each year |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = [[Day of the Shining Star]] (16 February), [[Day of the Sun]] (15 April), [[Day of the Foundation of the Republic (North Korea)|Day of the Foundation of the Republic]] (9 September) }} The '''Party Foundation Day''' is an annual [[Public holidays in North Korea|public holiday]] in [[North Korea]] marking the 10 October 1945 foundation of the "Central Organizing Committee of the Communist Party of North Korea", known as the "[[North Korea Bureau of the Communist Party of Korea|North Korea Bureau]] of the [[Communist Party of Korea]]" in the West and considered a predecessor to the ruling [[Workers' Party of Korea]].
Celebrations include political speeches, artistic performances and mass events including military parades. Ordinary citizens receive food rations and electricity.
The Party Founding Day is one of the most important holidays of the country, along with the [[Day of the Sun]] (birthday of [[Kim Il-sung]]), [[Day of the Shining Star]] (birthday of [[Kim Jong-il]]) and [[Day of the Foundation of the Republic (North Korea)|Day of the Foundation of the Republic]].<ref name="Seoul2002">{{cite book|author=Yonhap News Agency, Seoul|title=North Korea Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JIlh9nNeadMC&pg=PA451|date=27 December 2002|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=978-0-7656-3523-5|pages=451–452}}</ref> 2015 marked the 70th anniversary.
==Background== [[File:Party Foundation Museum.jpg|thumb|The public hall where the founding conference was held now hosts the [[Party Founding Museum]].]] North Korea commemorates 10 October 1945 as the date of the foundation of the "Central Organizing Committee of the Communist Party of North Korea",<ref name="JoAn2002">{{cite book|author1=Am Jo|author2=Chol Gang An|title=Korea in the 20th century: 100 significant events|year=2002|location=Pyongyang|publisher=Foreign Languages Publishing House|oclc=276996886|page=84}}</ref> known as the "[[North Korea Bureau of the Communist Party of Korea|North Korea Bureau]] of the [[Communist Party of Korea]]" by Western historians.<ref name="Armstrong2013"/>
On 10 October 1945 a meeting called "Conference of Korean Communist Party Members and Enthusiasts in the Five Northwestern Provinces" began in [[Pyongyang]],<ref name="Armstrong2013"/> in a public hall that now hosts the [[Party Founding Museum]].<ref name="Corfield2014">{{cite book|last=Corfield|first=Justin|title=Historical Dictionary of Pyongyang|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5zKWBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA159|date=1 December 2014|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=978-1-78308-341-1|page=159}}</ref> On 13 October, the meeting saw the establishment of the North Korea Bureau of the Communist Party of Korea. The conference was the first time that Kim Il-sung emerged as a political force.<ref name="NK_This"/> Kim advocated the foundation of the North Korea Bureau so that party activities could be overseen in the north of the country in a situation where the north and south were [[Division of Korea|occupied]] by the [[Soviet Civil Administration|Soviets]] and the [[United States Army Military Government in Korea|Americans]] respectively.<ref name="Armstrong2013">{{cite book|first=Charles K.|last=Armstrong|title=The North Korean Revolution, 1945–1950|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eUf-_XACg3UC&pg=PA58|date=15 April 2013|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0-8014-6879-5|page=58}}</ref> Kim acceded the chairmanship of the North Korea Bureau some two months after the conference.<ref name="NK_This"/> The Bureau soon became independent of the [[Seoul]]-lead Communist Party of Korea,<ref name="NK_This"/> paving the way for a political force in the North.<ref name="Armstrong2013"/>
The North Korea Bureau is one in a series of predecessors to the present Workers' Party of Korea. The North Korea Bureau [[1st Congress of the Workers' Party of North Korea|evolved into]] the [[Workers' Party of North Korea]] in August 1946.<ref name="NK_This"/> The present Workers' Party of Korea was not founded until 30 June 1949 when the Workers' Party of North Korea [[History of the Workers' Party of Korea#Founding|merged with]] the [[Workers' Party of South Korea]].<ref name="ency_Founding"/>
==Celebrations== [[File:Party Foundation Monument (15362632418).jpg|thumb|A tour guide visiting the Monument to Party Founding in Pyongyang around the anniversary]] Celebrations include song and dance performances, evening galas, speeches, lectures on revolutionary history and oratorical meetings.<ref name="ency_Founding"/><ref name="dail_Autu"/> Floral tributes are laid in front of statues of Kim Il-sung.<ref name="NK_This">{{Cite web | title = This Day in History: When Kim Il Sung Took Power | last = Gauthier|first=Brandon K. | publisher = NK News | date = 9 October 2012 | accessdate = 9 September 2015 | url = http://www.nknews.org/2012/10/this-day-in-history-when-kim-il-sung-took-power/}}</ref> Special food rations are distributed.<ref name="dail_Subd">{{Cite web | title = Subdued Atmosphere for Party Foundation Day | trans-title = | author1 = Choi Song Min|author2=Kwon Hyo Jin | work = [[Daily NK]] | date = 11 October 2014 | accessdate = 9 September 2015 | url = http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=12407 }}</ref> This usually includes foodstuffs that are normally in short supply, such as oil and snacks.<ref name="dail_Food">{{Cite web | title = Food Distributed to Pyongyang on 66th | author = Lee Seok Young | work = dailynk.com | date = 14 October 2011 | accessdate = 11 September 2015 | url = http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=8285}}</ref> Meat is available through the [[Public distribution system (North Korea)|public distribution system]].<ref name="FordKwon2007">{{cite book|last1=Glyn|last2=Soyoung|title=North Korea on the brink: struggle for survival|url=http://site.ebrary.com/lib/alltitles/docDetail.action?docID=10479620&p96|year=2007|publisher=Pluto Press|isbn=978-1-84964-332-0|page=96|via=ProQuest ebrary}}</ref>
Electricity is provided on the Party Foundation Day, despite shortages.<ref name="dail_Elec">{{Cite web | title = Electricity Resumption in Border Area, Temporary | author = Kang Jae Hyok | work = dailynk.com | date = 21 December 2006 | accessdate = 10 September 2015 | url = http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk00100&num=1468 }}</ref> There are live TV broadcasts of ceremonies.<ref name="dail_Autu">{{Cite web | title = Autumn in North Korea is Period of Suffering | author = Lee Joo Il | work = dailynk.com | date = 2 September 2005 | accessdate = 10 September 2015 | url = http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01300&num=270 }}</ref> The holiday is celebrated throughout the country, though main celebrations take place in the capital, Pyongyang.<ref name="ency_Founding">{{Cite book| title = Founding of the Workers' Party of North Korea| publisher = Omnigraphics| via = TheFreeDictionary.com| work = Holidays, Festivals, and Celebrations of the World Dictionary| edition = Fourth| date = 2010| accessdate = 9 September 2015| url = http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Founding+of+the+Workers'+Party+of+North+Korea}}</ref> The city typically hosts processions and a military parade during the day. Attendance in festivities in the capital is counted in the millions.<ref name="WorldTradePress2010">{{cite book|title=North Korea Society and Culture Complete Report|url=http://site.ebrary.com/lib/alltitles/docDetail.action?docID=10389224&p05|year=2010|publisher=World Trade Press|location=Petaluma, CA, USA|isbn=978-1-60780-406-2|page=5|via=ProQuest ebrary}}</ref>
The celebrations have included occasional ceremonial visits of [[List of leaders of North Korea|North Korean leaders]] to the [[Kumsusan Palace of the Sun]]. The failure of [[Kim Jong-un]] to appear in 2014 intensified speculations of his lengthy absence. The tradition has not been very strong, as in comparison to Kim Jong-un, his father [[Kim Jong-il]] observed the same tradition only twice.<ref name="Grisafi_2014">{{cite web |url=http://www.nknews.org/2014/10/kim-jong-un-still-a-no-show-but-coup-unlikely/ |title=Kim Jong Un still a no-show, but coup unlikely |last=Grisafi |first=John G. |date=10 October 2014 |website= |publisher= |access-date=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Donga_2014">{{cite web |url=http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2014101165938 |title=Kim Jong Un fails to appear on Workers’ Party foundation day |date=11 October 2014 |website= |publisher= |access-date=9 September 2015}}</ref>
North Korea schedules completion of large-scale construction projects to coincide with important anniversaries like the Party Foundation Day.<ref name="ifes_NKBr">{{Cite web | title = North Korea Encourages Completion of Large-Scale Projects to Coincide with 2015 Party Foundation Day | work = ifes.kyungnam.ac.kr | date = 12 June 2014 | accessdate = 10 September 2015 | url = http://ifes.kyungnam.ac.kr/eng/FRM/FRM_0101V.aspx?code=FRM140612_0001 }}</ref> The 1995 50th anniversary of the party, for instance, was met with unveiling of the [[Monument to Party Founding]].<ref name="FrankHoare2009">{{cite book|editor-last1=Frank|editor-first1=Rüdiger|editor-last2=Hoare|editor-first2=Jim |editor-last3=Kölner|editor-first3=Patrick|editor4-last=Pares|editor4-first=Susan|title=Korea Yearbook (2009): Politics, Economy and Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CmaWblhxJsEC&pg=PA44|year=2009|publisher=BRILL|location=Leiden|isbn=90-04-18019-2|page=44}}</ref> The 70th anniversary in 2015 was planned to be celebrated with the completion of a stock breeding base and a power plant: the [[Sepho]] Tableland and the [[Chongchon River]] Power Plant.<ref name="ifes_NKBr"/> The latter was finished by the next month.<ref>{{Cite web | title = N. Korea completes 10 hydro plants | last = Byrne | first = Leo | work = NK News | date = 18 November 2015 | accessdate = 3 August 2016| url = https://www.nknews.org/2015/11/n-korea-completes-10-hydro-plants/ }}</ref>
Banks, offices, retail and government institutions close for the day.<ref name="WorldTradePress2010"/> Weddings are often organized on the day.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Toimela|first1=Markku|last2=Aalto|first2=Kaj|title= Salakahvilla Pohjois-Koreassa: Markku Toimelan jännittävä tie Pohjois-Korean luottomieheksi|year=2017|publisher=Docendo|location=Jyväskylä|language=fi|isbn=978-952-291-369-2|page=40}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|North Korea|Holidays}} *[[Public holidays in North Korea]] *[[Down-with-Imperialism Union]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|editor=Chosŏn sanŏp nodong chosaso [Research Institute for Korean Industry and Labor]|title=Orhŭn nosŏn|trans-title=The Correct Line|location=Tokyo|publisher=Minjung sinmunsa|date=1946|pages=30–48|oclc=122860423|postscript=  – minutes of the founding conference.}} *{{cite book|author=Kim Il-sung|title=On building a Marxist-Leninist party in our country and its immediate tasks: report to the inaugural congress of the Central Organizing Committee of the Communist Party of North Korea, October 10, 1945|date=1975|location=Pyongyang|publisher=Foreign Languages Publishing House|oclc=14062478|postscript=  – Kim Il-sung's speech at the founding conference.}} *{{Cite web | title = Why North Korea celebrates Party Foundation Day | last = Tertitskiy | first = Fyodor | work = NK News | date = 10 October 2017 | url = https://www.nknews.org/2017/10/why-north-korea-celebrates-party-foundation-day/ }} {{refend}}
==External links== *[http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/event/?part=20151010/ Party Foundation Day] at [[Naenara]] *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2015/oct/09/north-korea-70th-birthday-party-in-pictures Pictures of preparations, 2015] at [[theguardian.com]] *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/11921914/North-Korea-gears-up-for-70th-anniversary-of-Workers-Party-in-pictures.html Pictures of preparations, 2015] at [[Telegraph.co.uk]] *[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34497425 2015 military parade in pictures] at [[BBC.com]] *{{YouTube|PzPvhrh7gLM|The full 2015 military parade}}
